body.p: HPE Helion OpenStack is an OpenStack technology coupled with a version of Linux provided by HP. This topic describes all the known issues that you might encounter. To help you resolve these issues, we have provided possible solutions.
For easy reference, we categorized the known issues and solutions as follows:

section.title: Fatal PCI Express Device Error
section.p: When installing on HPE ProLiant SL390s and HPE ProLiant BL490d systems, the following error has occasionally occurred:

codeblock.codeph: `Fatal PCI Express Device Error PCI Slot ? B00/D00/F00`

section.p: If you get this error, reset the system that experienced the error:

ol.li: Connect to the iLO using Internet Explorer: https://<iLO IP address>
Navigate to Information / Diagnostics.
Reset iLO.
Log back into the iLO after 30 seconds.
Navigate to Remote Console / Remote Console.
Open the integrated remote console (.NET).
Click Power switch / Press and Hold.

li.p: Click Power switch / Momentary Press, and wait for the system to restart.
The system should now boot normally.

If the overcloud controller is rebooted (due to a power issue, hardware upgrade, or similar event), OpenStack compute tools such as nova-list might report that the VMs are in an ERROR state, rendering the overcloud unusable. To restore the overcloud to an operational state, follow the steps below:
As user root on the overcloud controller you must:
A. Run the os-refresh-config scripts:
B. Restart the mysql service:
C. Re-run the os-refresh-config scripts:
D. Restart all Networking Operations (Neutron) services:

codeblock.codeph:
# service neutron-dhcp-agent restart # service neutron-l3-agent restart
# service neutron-metadata-agent restart # service neutron-openvswitch-agent restart # service neutron-server restart

li.p: On each overcloud node, restart the Neutron and Nova services:

codeblock.codeph: $ sudo service neutron-openvswitch-agent restart $ sudo service nova-compute restart $ sudo service nova-scheduler restart $ sudo service nova-conductor restart

li.p: The installer uses IPMI commands to reset nodes and change their power status. Some systems change to a state in which the Server Power status as reported by the iLO is stuck in RESET. If this occurs, you must physically disconnect the power from the server for 10 seconds. If the problem persists after that, contact HPE Support as there might be a defective component in the system.

On the system on which the installer is run, the seed VM's networking is bridged onto the external LAN. If you remove HPE Helion OpenStack the network bridge persists. To revert the network configuration to its pre-installation state, run the following commands as user root:

codeblock.codeph: # ip addr add 192.168.185.131/16 dev eth0 scope global # ip addr del 192.168.185.131/16 dev brbm # ovs-vsctl del-port NIC

li.p: where

ul.li: 192.168.185.131 is the IP address on the external interface - you should replace this with your own IP address.
The baremetal bridge is always called 'brbm'

li.p: Before you install the HPE Helion OpenStack DNSaaS or if you want to use Heat with HP Helion OpenStack you must modify the /etc/heat/heat.conf file on the overcloud controller as follows.
Important: The installation of the HPE Helion OpenStack DNSaaS fails if you do not make these modifications.
Make sure the IP address in the following settings reflects the IP address of the overcloud controller, for example:

codeblock.codeph: heat_metadata_server_url = http://192.0.202.2:8000 heat_waitcondition_server_url = http://192.0.202.2:8000/v1/waitcondition heat_watch_server_url = http://192.0.202.2:8003

li.p: Note: You must have admin ssh access to the overcloud controller.
Save the file.
Restart the Heat-related services - heat-api, heat-api-cfn, heat-api-cloudwatch, and heat-engine.
Ensure there are no Heat resources in an error state, and then delete any stale or corrupted Heat-related stacks.

section.title: IPMI fails with an error- unable to establish IPMI v2 / RMCP+ session
section.p: When installing on HPE ProLiant BL490c systems, the following error has occasionally occurred:

codeblock.codeph: unable to establish IPMI v2 / RMCP+ session

section.p: If you get this error, perform the following steps:

ol.li: Ensure that the iLO user has administrator privileges, which is required by the IPMITOOL.
To check from the iLO remote console, reboot the server and press F8 to get to ILO Management screen.
Click User in the menu-bar and select Edit. Edit User pop-up box displays .
If you are using a BL server in the QA C7000 enclosure, select the cdl user to edit.
Use ↓(down arrow key) to select Administer User Accounts.
Use the space bar to set the value to YES.
Select F10 to save.
Click File and select Exit to close.

section.title: Installation failure as the flavor to be used for overcloud nodes does not match
section.p: If you have a set of Baremetal servers which differ in specifications (e.g. memory and disk), the installation will fail as the flavor to be used for overcloud nodes does not match with the server that has the lowest specification for memory, disk, and CPU.
The 2nd row in baremetal.csv which corresponds to the overcloud Controller node is used to create a flavor for the overcloud nodes.
Edit the baremetal.csv file to define the lowest specification server in the second row.

section.title: PXE boot on target node keeps switching between interfaces
section.p: When node boots up on iLO console it shows node waiting for PXE boot on multiple NICs.
Multiple NICs are enabled for Network Boot.

ul.li: Reboot the node, using F9 to get to the BIOS configuration.
Assuming NIC1(eth0/em1) for the node is connected to a private network shared across node enable it for Network Boot.
Set NIC 1 Boot Options = Network Boot.

section.title: BIOS blocks are not set to correct date and time across all nodes
section.p: Nodes PXE boot but ISCSI does not start.
Time and date across nodes are incorrect.
Reboot the node, using F9 to get to the BIOS configuration. BIOS date and time are set correctly and the same on all the systems.

ul.li: Use the <ENTER> key to accept the new date and time.
Save the BIOS, which reboots the node again.
Once the node has rebooted, you can confirm its data and time from the iLO Overview.

section.title: iLO console shows hLinux daemon.err tgtd while PXE booting
section.p: PXE boot gets stuck after daemon.err tgtd
Node does not have enough disk space

ul.li: Check if target node has disk space mentioned in baremetal.csv and is greater than Node_min_disk mentioned in tripleo/tripleo-incubator/scripts/hp_ced_functions.sh.
If disk space is less than Node_min_disk, change Node_min_disk along with DISK_SIZE in tripleo/tripleo-incubator/scripts/hp_ced_list_nodes.sh on Seed.

section.title: iLO console shows null waiting for notice of completion while PXE booting
section.p: Node is powered on and PXE booted but it is powered off after daemon.err and stack create fails.
Node does not have enough disk space. SAN boot is enabled for node or local disk is not attached to /sda
Installer expects that SAN boot option is disabled for nodes. Verify whether SAN boot is disabled for BL 490c.
Also, you can boot the targeted BL490c with Ubuntu or any Linux ISO to see what device is shown as the local disk. For the installer it should be /sda.

section.title: Failure of Hp_ced_installer.sh
section.p: Hp_ced_installer.sh fails because of baremetal.csv /sda.
Verify baremetal.csv for empty lines or special characters.

section.title: Failure of Seed Installation
section.p: Seed installation fails with no space left on device.
Verify the tripleo directory- user owner and group. It must be root:root. Incase it is not set as root:root then edit it to root using- chown root:root tripleo
Inconsistent Rabbitmq failure seen on controller nodes while listing queues
Restart the Rabbitmq service.

If the update fails, from undercloud node:

Execute the heat stack-list command to determine which Heat stack is in an error state. The stack will have a status of CREATE_FAILED.
Execute the ironic node-list command to determine which node(s) is in maintenance mode. The stack will have a maintenance of TRUE.

section.title: Installation script detects more than 7 available drive
section.p: Maximum supported devices 7.
This issue occurs when there are more than 7 available drives detected by the installation script to deploy StoreVirtual.
Perform the following steps:

li.p: HPE StoreVirtual VSA supports up to 7 disks
Execute fdisk -l and check for number of available drives in the machine other than /dev/sda

section.title: Failure of script due to less than two drives
section.p: Minimum number of disks must be 2. No disks are available.
Probable Cause When there are less than two drives in the machine, the script will fail to execute.
To resolve, perform the following steps:

li.p: Execute fdisk -l
Minimum two drives and maximum of 7 drives should be available for the StoreVirtual deployment other than boot disk(/dev/sda)
At least three drives required for enabling AO

section.title: Cannot enable AO as only one disk is available
section.p: For Adaptive Optimization to be enabled, at least three drives must be available. /dev/sdb must be SSD drive(Tier 0) and the remaining will be Tier 1.
To resolve the issue, do the following:

li.p: Use RAID controllers to create RAID groups.
Ensure that you create the RAID group for SSD drives immediately after creating the RAID group for boot volume. For example: If three RAID groups are to be created. The following is recommended :
Step 1 : Create the first RAID group for HDD drives and mark this as boot volume(/dev/sda)
Step 2: Create the second RAID group for SSD drives which should be used as Tier 0 for AO (/dev/sdb)
Step 3: Create the third RAID group for HDD drives which will be used as Tier 1(/dev/sdc)

section.title: Scale-out nodes : os-refresh-config on Controller Nodes Fail
section.p: The os-refresh-config on controller Nodes fail during scale-out.
The controller nodes can fail due to following reasons:

li.p: wrong user input
rabbitmq clustering
mysql clustering
Use the following command and verify the running status of rabbitmq.
If rabbitmq is not running, start rabbitmq using start rabbitmq-server command.

Verify that the rabbitmqctl cluster_status displays all 3 nodes in running_nodes, disc. If it does not display one or more nodes in running nodes then restart rabbitmq and run the following command on the missing nodes:
If rabbitmqctl cluster_status shows expected output but there is an issue with one or more node(s) for joining rabbitmq cluster, do the following:
Execute the following commands on all controller nodes:
Run os-refresh-config command first on the cluster_name (rabbitmqctl cluster_status output) and on the remaining controller nodes.
Use the following command and verify the running status of mysql on the node.
If mysql has stopped, restart it.
If mysql fails to restart, perform the following instructions:

ul.li: Run mysqld_safe --wsrep-recover on all controller nodes.

li.p: Compare the output from all controller nodes for last committed transaction sequence number. For example:

codeblock.codeph: root@overcloud-ce-controller-controller0-defen5afl75f:~# mysqld_safe --wsrep-recover sed: -e expression #1, char 25: unknown option to `s' sed: -e expression #1, char 24: unknown option to `s' 141113 01:00:36 mysqld_safe Logging to '/mnt/state/var/log/mysql/error.log'. 141113 01:00:36 mysqld_safe Starting mysqld daemon with databases from /mnt/state/var/lib/mysql/ 141113 01:00:36 mysqld_safe Skipping wsrep-recover for 1e9d939a-6a07-11e4-9c28-aa31223485e0:220764 pair 141113 01:00:36 mysqld_safe Assigning 1e9d939a-6a07-11e4-9c28-aa31223485e0:220764 to wsrep_start_position 141113 01:00:38 mysqld_safe mysqld from pid file /var/run/mysqld/mysqld.pid ended

li.p: So the last committed transaction sequence number on this node is 220764.

ul.li: Compare the last committed transaction sequence number across all 3 nodes and bootstrap from the latest node using /etc/init.d/mysql bootstrap-pxc or /etc/init.d/mysql restart and start mysql on the remaining nodes.

section.title: Logging
Issue in Logging
section.p: The user needs to manually follow the below steps to re-configure Kibana for logging.

ol.li: Log in to the undercloud and start screen session.

In the screen, start following command sudo -u logstash /usr/bin/java -Xmx1g -Djava.io.tmpdir=/var/lib/logstash/ -jar /opt/logstash/logstash.jar agent -f /etc/logstash/conf.d -w 10 --log /var/log/logstash/logstash.log
Press Control & 'a', then 'c' to create another shell.

In a new shell execute command sudo -u logstash /usr/bin/java -Xmx1g -Djava.io.tmpdir=/var/lib/logstash/ -jar /opt/logstash/logstash.jar agent -f /etc/logstash/conf.d -w 10 --log /var/log/logstash/logstash.log
Repeat steps from 3-4 two times
Press Control & 'a' then 'd' to detach.

section.p: Note: If node reboots repeat the step from 1-6.
